metadata.titleEn: Organic matter and grain size data of Dalongchi, central Tianshan Mountains
metadata.description: This dataset includes 842 organic matter and 899 grain size data from Dalongchi in the central Tianshan Mountains. Samples were taken at intervals of 1cm for the determination of organic matter and particle size. This dataset can be used to analyze climate conditions over the past millennium. The results suggest that the Medieval Warm Period (MWP) and Modern Warm Period (CWP) had a dry climate, while the Little Ice Age (LIA) had a wet climate, which may be related to the influence of NAO and AMO. In addition, humidity oscillations are violent and unstable on multidecadal to century scales. Especially during the Little Ice Age, there were 4 wet periods and 3 dry periods. The influence of solar cycle and ENSO quasi-regular cycle should be emphasized in future hydroclimate prediction and climate simulation in arid Central Asia.

background: Arid Central Asia (ACA), far away from the ocean, is not only one of the driest and largest inland regions worldwide, but also the birthplace of the far-reaching ancient civilizations that spread along the Silk Road. Scarce precipitation, intense evaporation, and fragile ecosystems render this region sensitive to abrupt changes in effective humidity. Arid Central Asia is primarily controlled by the prevailing westerlies. Proxy records from ACA are valuable for understanding the driving factors and processes of underlying hydroclimate evolution in the inland region, which provides useful reference for human adaptation to hydroclimate changes at present and into the future. On the sub-orbital scale, solar radiation controlled the intensity of the westerlies through the variation of the meridional radiation gradient between high and middle latitudes, thus having the dominant influence on moisture changes of ACA during the Holocene. In addition, the sub-orbital-scale hydroclimate changes are also related to the shift of the Subtropical High, the strength and position of the Siberian High, North Atlantic Oscillation (NAO) mode, and the changes of the Laurentide and Scandinavian Ice Sheets. In earlier studies, a humid climate during the MWP and a dry climate condition during the LIA was documented by the tree ring of Sabina przewalskii (Kom.). However, a growing body of studies based on the lacustrine sediments, ice cores, tree ring, and peat profiles show a generally similar climate pattern of a relatively dry MWP and a wet LIA in ACA over the last millennium. Many studies emphasize that internal climate variability (i.e., major sea and atmospheric modes) is supposed to be more marked than external factors (e.g., solar forcing) in influencing hydroclimate changes.
research objective: Here, we provide a continuous high-resolution humidity history in arid Central Asia over the past millennium based on the ∼1.8-year high-resolution multiproxy records with good chronological control from Lake Dalongchi in the central Tian Shan. Then, we explore the contribution of internal climate variability (which mainly refers to the NAO, AMO, and ENSO in this study) and solar activity to humidity oscillations on different timescales over the past millennium. Our findings suggest that the effect of the solar cycle and the quasi-regular period of ENSO should be seriously evaluated for hydroclimate predictions and climate simulations in arid Central Asia in the future.
challenges: These controversies are largely attributed to low-resolution records or chronological uncertainties due to the old carbon effect, which limit our understanding of the hydroclimate evolution on decadal to centennial scales and of the relative role of external and internal drivers over the past millennium.
methods: In July 2018 and August 2019, we retrieved several parallel long sediment cores from Lake Dalongchi at a maximum water depth of 7.4 m using the UWITEC platform manufactured in Austria, and several short cores using a piston gravity corer. The DLC1819 core was subsampled at 1 cm intervals. All subsamples were stored in a freezer in our laboratory at a constant temperature of 4 ◦C and used for MS, grain size, total organic carbon (TOC), and total nitrogen (TN) analyses. Samples for MS were dried at below 40 ◦C in a constant temperature air-blast drying oven and ground and packed into standard plastic boxes with a capacity of 2·2·2 cm3. A Bartington MS2 susceptibility meter was used to measure magnetic susceptibility. Samples used for grain size measurement were pretreated with 10–20 mL of 10 % H 2O2 to remove organic matter and then with 10 mL of 10 % HCl to remove carbonates; next, samples were rinsed with deionized water and finally treated with 10 mL 0.05 M (NaPO3)6 on an ultrasonic vibrator for 10 min to promote dispersion. Grain size distributions were determined using Malvern/MS 3000 laser grain size analyzer. The samples used for TOC and TN determination were decalcified with 10 % HCl and rinsed repeatedly with deionized water. Then, ∼3–5 mg dried and ground samples were analyzed using the EURO EA 3000 elemental analyzer.
dataset: The reconstructed humidity index in this study has been submitted to the datasets of the 4TU Center for Research Data, which can will be permanently available at https://doi.org/10.4121/16570398 (Feng et al., 2022).
findings: The HI changes show that the climate was dry during the MWP (1180–1420 CE) and CWP (1920–2018 CE) and wet during the LIA (1420–1920 CE). Four wet episodes with the sharp high HI values were recorded for 1420–1470, 1550–1600, 1650–1720, and 1800–1920 CE, and three dramatic dry periods with the low HI values were recorded for 1470–1550, 1600–1650, and 1720–1800 CE during the LIA. The HI increased significantly and reached its peak during the several grand solar minimums (Wolf, Spörer, Maunder, Dalton), whereas the humidity decreased rapidly in the maximum solar activity period.

Definition.Question: What is meant by 'magnetic susceptibility' in sediment analysis, and how is it relevant to climate research?
Definition.Answer: 'Magnetic susceptibility' in sediment analysis refers to the measure of how much a sediment sample can be magnetized in response to an applied magnetic field. It is relevant to climate research as it helps in interpreting past environmental conditions, including changes in sediment composition and deposition processes, which can be linked to historical climate variations.

Comparison.Question: How do the data collection methods for organic matter and grain size in sediment cores compare to those used for tree ring analysis in terms of resolution and chronological control?
Comparison.Answer: In sediment cores, organic matter and grain size data were collected at 1 cm intervals, providing high-resolution records with good chronological control. This method offers detailed insights into past climate conditions over the past millennium. In contrast, tree ring analysis provides chronological data based on annual growth layers, which may have limitations in resolution and can be influenced by factors such as carbon dating uncertainties.

Comparison.Question: What are the differences in challenges faced when reconstructing hydroclimate history using lacustrine sediments versus ice cores?
Comparison.Answer: Reconstructing hydroclimate history using lacustrine sediments faces challenges such as low-resolution records and chronological uncertainties, often due to the old carbon effect. These issues can limit the understanding of decadal to centennial hydroclimate evolution. In contrast, ice cores may offer more precise chronological data but can be limited by geographical availability and potential contamination.

Interpretation.Question: How do the subsampling intervals and analysis methods used in the data collection process affect the understanding of hydroclimate evolution over the past millennium?
Interpretation.Answer: The data was subsampled at 1 cm intervals, which provides high-resolution records, and various analyses such as MS, grain size, TOC, and TN analyses help in understanding hydroclimate evolution. Low-resolution records or chronological uncertainties due to the old carbon effect pose challenges, limiting understanding on decadal to centennial scales.

Interpretation.Question: What insights do the changes in humidity index provide about the climate conditions during different historical periods, and what methodologies can be applied to validate these insights?
Interpretation.Answer: The changes in the humidity index show that the climate was dry during the MWP and CWP and wet during the LIA, with specific wet and dry episodes recorded. Methodologies to validate these insights include comparing with proxy records such as lacustrine sediments, ice cores, tree rings, and peat profiles, which emphasize internal climate variability and external factors like solar forcing.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why are specific pretreatment steps necessary in the process of grain size measurement during data collection?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Specific pretreatment steps are necessary in the process of grain size measurement to remove organic matter and carbonates from the samples. This involves treating samples with hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) to remove organic matter, hydrochloric acid (HCl) to remove carbonates, rinsing with deionized water, and using sodium hexametaphosphate (NaPO3)6 on an ultrasonic vibrator to promote dispersion, which ensures accurate grain size distribution measurement using a laser grain size analyzer.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What are the underlying causes for the observed changes in humidity indices during different historical periods in arid Central Asia?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The observed changes in humidity indices during different historical periods in arid Central Asia are influenced by a combination of factors, including the effects of the solar cycle and quasi-regular periods of ENSO. The climate was found to be dry during the Medieval Warm Period (MWP) and the Current Warm Period (CWP), and wet during the Little Ice Age (LIA). These changes appear to be associated with internal climate variability factors such as the NAO, AMO, and ENSO, as well as solar activity.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to collect parallel long sediment cores and subsample them at 1 cm intervals for hydroclimate research in arid Central Asia?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Collecting parallel long sediment cores and subsampling them at 1 cm intervals is crucial for obtaining high-resolution multiproxy records with good chronological control, which allows for a more detailed and accurate reconstruction of past humidity changes on different timescales. This approach helps in understanding the contribution of internal climate variability and solar activity to hydroclimate oscillations over the past millennium.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why focus on the influence of both solar cycles and ENSO quasi-regular periods when predicting future hydroclimate changes in arid Central Asia?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Focusing on the influence of both solar cycles and ENSO quasi-regular periods is necessary because they have been shown to significantly affect humidity oscillations on different timescales. Understanding these influences is crucial for improving hydroclimate predictions and simulations, which are vital for future water resource management and climate adaptation strategies in the arid Central Asia region.

High-resolution multiproxy records were used to maintain good chronological control.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How are sediment samples prepared and analyzed for grain size distribution in climate studies?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Sediment samples are pretreated with hydrogen peroxide to remove organic matter, then with hydrochloric acid to remove carbonates. They are rinsed with deionized water and treated with sodium hexametaphosphate on an ultrasonic vibrator to promote dispersion. Grain size distributions are determined using a laser grain size analyzer.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What methods are used to analyze organic content in sediment samples collected for reconstructing historical climate conditions?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: To analyze organic content, sediment samples are decalcified with hydrochloric acid and rinsed with deionized water. Dried and ground samples are then analyzed using an elemental analyzer to determine total organic carbon and total nitrogen.

Enablement.Question: What technological advancements enable the high-resolution analysis of sediment cores for climate studies in arid Central Asia?
Enablement.Answer: The use of the UWITEC platform for retrieving sediment cores and advanced analytical equipment like the Malvern/MS 3000 laser grain size analyzer and the EURO EA 3000 elemental analyzer enable high-resolution analysis of sediment cores. These technologies facilitate precise measurement of grain size, organic carbon, and nitrogen, crucial for climate studies in arid Central Asia.

Enablement.Question: How do specific data collection methods address challenges related to chronological uncertainties in hydroclimate evolution studies?
Enablement.Answer: Sampling at 1 cm intervals and storing subsamples at a constant temperature help mitigate chronological uncertainties by providing a continuous and well-preserved record. The use of magnetic susceptibility and grain size analysis further refines chronological control, addressing challenges related to chronological uncertainties.

Enablement.Question: What conditions or methodologies enable the interpretation of past climate conditions using sediment data from inland regions?
Enablement.Answer: The combination of multiproxy records, including organic carbon and nitrogen content, grain size distributions, and magnetic susceptibility, allows for the interpretation of past climate conditions. These methodologies, alongside chronological control, enable detailed analysis of climate oscillations and their drivers, such as solar activity and internal climate variability.

Expectation.Question: Why might researchers expect chronological uncertainties in hydroclimate data from Arid Central Asia, and what are some potential approaches to address these uncertainties?
Expectation.Answer: Chronological uncertainties can arise due to the old carbon effect and low-resolution records. Researchers might use high-resolution multiproxy records with good chronological control to mitigate these uncertainties and improve understanding of hydroclimate evolution.

Judgmental.Question: How would you judge the effectiveness of using grain size and organic matter analyses in reconstructing past climate conditions?
Judgmental.Answer: Grain size and organic matter analyses can be effective in reconstructing past climate conditions as they offer insights into sediment deposition processes and organic content changes over time. These methods, used in conjunction with other proxies, provide a detailed understanding of past climate conditions, although their effectiveness may be limited by potential uncertainties in chronological control and the need for careful pretreatment to ensure accuracy.

Judgmental.Question: What are your thoughts on the challenges faced when reconstructing historical climate data from inland regions like Arid Central Asia?
Judgmental.Answer: Reconstructing historical climate data from inland regions like Arid Central Asia presents challenges such as low-resolution records and chronological uncertainties. These issues can hinder the understanding of hydroclimate evolution and the role of external and internal climate drivers. Addressing these challenges requires high-resolution multiproxy records with robust chronological control to enhance the reliability and accuracy of climate reconstructions.
